member.returns: One of the System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult values.

member.name: T:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric
member.summary:
Flags used with the Windows API (User32.dll):GetSystemMetrics(SystemMetric smIndex)
This Enum and declaration signature was written by Gabriel T. Sharp ai_productions@verizon.net or osirisgothra@hotmail.com Obtained on pinvoke.net, please contribute your code to support the wiki!

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_ARRANGE
member.summary: The flags that specify how the system arranged minimized windows. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CLEANBOOT
member.summary: The value that specifies how the system is started: 0 Normal boot 1 Fail-safe boot 2 Fail-safe with network boot A fail-safe boot (also called SafeBoot, Safe Mode, or Clean Boot) bypasses the user startup files.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CMONITORS
member.summary: The number of display monitors on a desktop. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CMOUSEBUTTONS
member.summary: The number of buttons on a mouse, or zero if no mouse is installed.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXBORDER
member.summary: The width of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CXEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXCURSOR
member.summary: The width of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CXFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The width of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. , The second click must occur within the rectangle that is defined by SM_CXDOUBLECLK and SM_CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time. To set the width of the double-click rectangle, call SystemParametersInfo with SPI_SETDOUBLECLKWIDTH.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels on either side of a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from the left of the mouse-down point and added to the right of it.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXEDGE
member.summary: The width of a 3-D border, in pixels. This metric is the 3-D counterpart of SM_CXBORDER.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. SM_CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border, and SM_CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CXDLGFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The width of the left and right edges of the focus rectangle that the DrawFocusRectdraws. This value is in pixels. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CXSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen that is not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfofunction with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXHSCROLL
member.summary: The width of the arrow bitmap on a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXHTHUMB
member.summary: The width of the thumb box in a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXICON
member.summary: The default width of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions that SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON specifies.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXICONSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size SM_CXICONSPACING by SM_CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CXICON.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default width, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum width of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMENUCHECK
member.summary: The width of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMENUSIZE
member.summary: The width of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMIN
member.summary: The minimum width of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINIMIZED
member.summary: The width of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CXMINIMIZED.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking width of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXPADDEDBORDER
member.summary: The amount of border padding for captioned windows, in pixels. Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, HORZRES).

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXSIZE
member.summary: The width of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXSIZEFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. SM_CXSIZEFRAME is the width of the horizontal border, and SM_CYSIZEFRAME is the height of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CXFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXSMICON
member.summary: The recommended width of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXSMSIZE
member.summary: The width of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_XVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CXVSCROLL
member.summary: The width of a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYBORDER
member.summary: The height of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CYEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a caption area, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYCURSOR
member.summary: The height of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CYFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The height of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. The second click must occur within the rectangle defined by SM_CXDOUBLECLK and SM_CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time. To set the height of the double-click rectangle, call SystemParametersInfo with SPI_SETDOUBLECLKHEIGHT.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels above and below a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from above the mouse-down point and added below it.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYEDGE
member.summary: The height of a 3-D border, in pixels. This is the 3-D counterpart of SM_CYBORDER.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. SM_CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border, and SM_CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CYDLGFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The height of the top and bottom edges of the focus rectangle drawn byDrawFocusRect. This value is in pixels. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CYSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYHSCROLL
member.summary: The height of a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYICON
member.summary: The default height of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYICONSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size SM_CXICONSPACING by SM_CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CYICON.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYKANJIWINDOW
member.summary: For double byte character set versions of the system, this is the height of the Kanji window at the bottom of the screen, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default height, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum height of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMENU
member.summary: The height of a single-line menu bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMENUCHECK
member.summary: The height of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMENUSIZE
member.summary: The height of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMIN
member.summary: The minimum height of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMINIMIZED
member.summary: The height of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMINSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CYMINIMIZED.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking height of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, VERTRES).

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSIZE
member.summary: The height of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSIZEFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. SM_CXSIZEFRAME is the width of the horizontal border, and SM_CYSIZEFRAME is the height of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CYFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSMCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a small caption, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSMICON
member.summary: The recommended height of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYSMSIZE
member.summary: The height of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_YVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the coordinates for the top of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYVSCROLL
member.summary: The height of the arrow bitmap on a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_CYVTHUMB
member.summary: The height of the thumb box in a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_DBCSENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if User32.dll supports DBCS; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_DEBUG
member.summary: Nonzero if the debug version of User.exe is installed; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_DIGITIZER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The return value is a bitmask that specifies the type of digitizer input supported by the device. For more information, see Remarks. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_IMMENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if Input Method Manager/Input Method Editor features are enabled; otherwise, 0. SM_IMMENABLED indicates whether the system is ready to use a Unicode-based IME on a Unicode application. To ensure that a language-dependent IME works, check SM_DBCSENABLED and the system ANSI code page. Otherwise the ANSI-to-Unicode conversion may not be performed correctly, or some components like fonts or registry settings may not be present.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_MAXIMUMTOUCHES
member.summary: Nonzero if there are digitizers in the system; otherwise, 0. SM_MAXIMUMTOUCHES returns the aggregate maximum of the maximum number of contacts supported by every digitizer in the system. If the system has only single-touch digitizers, the return value is 1. If the system has multi-touch digitizers, the return value is the number of simultaneous contacts the hardware can provide. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_MEDIACENTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP, Media Center Edition, 0 if not.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_MENUDROPALIGNMENT
member.summary: Nonzero if drop-down menus are right-aligned with the corresponding menu-bar item; 0 if the menus are left-aligned.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_MIDEASTENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if the system is enabled for Hebrew and Arabic languages, 0 if not.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_MOUSEPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse is installed; otherwise, 0. This value is rarely zero, because of support for virtual mice and because some systems detect the presence of the port instead of the presence of a mouse.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_MOUSEHORIZONTALWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a horizontal scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_MOUSEWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a vertical scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_NETWORK
member.summary: The least significant bit is set if a network is present; otherwise, it is cleared. The other bits are reserved for future use.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_PENWINDOWS
member.summary: Nonzero if the Microsoft Windows for Pen computing extensions are installed; zero otherwise.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_REMOTECONTROL
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment to determine if the current Terminal Server session is being remotely controlled. Its value is nonzero if the current session is remotely controlled; otherwise, 0. You can use terminal services management tools such as Terminal Services Manager (tsadmin.msc) and shadow.exe to control a remote session. When a session is being remotely controlled, another user can view the contents of that session and potentially interact with it.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_REMOTESESSION
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment. If the calling process is associated with a Terminal Services client session, the return value is nonzero. If the calling process is associated with the Terminal Services console session, the return value is 0. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: The console session is not necessarily the physical console. For more information, seeWTSGetActiveConsoleSessionId.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_SAMEDISPLAYFORMAT
member.summary: Nonzero if all the display monitors have the same color format, otherwise, 0. Two displays can have the same bit depth, but different color formats. For example, the red, green, and blue pixels can be encoded with different numbers of bits, or those bits can be located in different places in a pixel color value.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_SECURE
member.summary: This system metric should be ignored; it always returns 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_SERVERR2
member.summary: The build number if the system is Windows Server 2003 R2; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_SHOWSOUNDS
member.summary: Nonzero if the user requires an application to present information visually in situations where it would otherwise present the information only in audible form; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_SHUTTINGDOWN
member.summary: Nonzero if the current session is shutting down; otherwise, 0. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_SLOWMACHINE
member.summary: Nonzero if the computer has a low-end (slow) processor; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_STARTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 Starter Edition, Windows Vista Starter, or Windows XP Starter Edition; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_SWAPBUTTON
member.summary: Nonzero if the meanings of the left and right mouse buttons are swapped; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_TABLETPC
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP Tablet PC edition or if the current operating system is Windows Vista or Windows 7 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The SM_DIGITIZER setting indicates the type of digitizer input supported by a device running Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2. For more information, see Remarks.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_XVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_CXVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the width of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.PI.SystemMetric.SM_YVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the top of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_CYVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the height of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.HWND_TOPMOST
member.summary: Places the window above all non-topmost windows. The window maintains its topmost position even when it is deactivated.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.HWND_NOTOPMOST
member.summary: Places the window above all non-topmost windows (that is, behind all topmost windows). This flag has no effect if the window is already a non-topmost window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.HWND_TOP
member.summary: Places the window at the top of the Z order.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.HWND_BOTTOM
member.summary: Places the window at the bottom of the Z order. If the hWnd parameter identifies a topmost window, the window loses its topmost status and is placed at the bottom of all other windows.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.NOSIZE
member.summary: Retains the current size (ignores the cx and cy parameters).

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.NOMOVE
member.summary: Retains the current position (ignores X and Y parameters).

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.NOZORDER
member.summary: Retains the current Z order (ignores the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.NOREDRAW
member.summary: Does not redraw changes. If this flag is set, no repainting of any kind occurs. This applies to the client area, the nonclient area (including the title bar and scroll bars), and any part of the parent window uncovered as a result of the window being moved. When this flag is set, the application must explicitly invalidate or redraw any parts of the window and parent window that need redrawing.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.NOACTIVATE
member.summary: Does not activate the window. If this flag is not set, the window is activated and moved to the top of either the topmost or non-topmost group (depending on the setting of the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.DRAWFRAME
member.summary: Draws a frame (defined in the window's class description) around the window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.FRAMECHANGED
member.summary: Applies new frame styles set using the SetWindowLong function. Sends a WM_NCCALCSIZE message to the window, even if the window's size is not being changed. If this flag is not specified, WM_NCCALCSIZE is sent only when the window's size is being changed.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.SHOWWINDOW
member.summary: Displays the window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.HIDEWINDOW
member.summary: Hides the window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.NOCOPYBITS
member.summary: Discards the entire contents of the client area. If this flag is not specified, the valid contents of the client area are saved and copied back into the client area after the window is sized or repositioned.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.NOOWNERZORDER
member.summary: Does not change the owner window's position in the Z order.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.NOREPOSITION
member.summary: Same as the SWP_NOOWNERZORDER flag.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.DONOTSENDCHANGINGEVENT
member.summary: Prevents the window from receiving the WM_WINDOWPOSCHANGING message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.DEFERERASE
member.summary: Prevents generation of the WM_SYNCPAINT message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SWP_.ASYNCWINDOWPOS
member.summary: If the calling thread and the thread that owns the window are attached to different input queues, the system posts the request to the thread that owns the window. This prevents the calling thread from blocking its execution while other threads process the request.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.BeepType.SimpleBeep
member.summary: A simple windows beep

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.BeepType.OK
member.summary: A standard windows OK beep

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.BeepType.Question
member.summary: A standard windows Question beep

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.BeepType.Exclamation
member.summary: A standard windows Exclamation beep

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.BeepType.Asterisk
member.summary: A standard windows Asterisk beep

member.name: T:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_
member.summary:
Flags used with the Windows API (User32.dll):GetSystemMetrics(SystemMetric smIndex)
This Enum and declaration signature was written by Gabriel T. Sharp ai_productions@verizon.net or osirisgothra@hotmail.com Obtained on pinvoke.net, please contribute your code to support the wiki!

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.ARRANGE
member.summary: The flags that specify how the system arranged minimized windows. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CLEANBOOT
member.summary: The value that specifies how the system is started: 0 Normal boot 1 Fail-safe boot 2 Fail-safe with network boot A fail-safe boot (also called SafeBoot, Safe Mode, or Clean Boot) bypasses the user startup files.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CMONITORS
member.summary: The number of display monitors on a desktop. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CMOUSEBUTTONS
member.summary: The number of buttons on a mouse, or zero if no mouse is installed.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXBORDER
member.summary: The width of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CXEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXCURSOR
member.summary: The width of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CXFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The width of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. , The second click must occur within the rectangle that is defined by SM_CXDOUBLECLK and SM_CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time. To set the width of the double-click rectangle, call SystemParametersInfo with SPI_SETDOUBLECLKWIDTH.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels on either side of a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from the left of the mouse-down point and added to the right of it.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXEDGE
member.summary: The width of a 3-D border, in pixels. This metric is the 3-D counterpart of SM_CXBORDER.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. SM_CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border, and SM_CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CXDLGFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The width of the left and right edges of the focus rectangle that the DrawFocusRectdraws. This value is in pixels. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CXSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen that is not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfofunction with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXHSCROLL
member.summary: The width of the arrow bitmap on a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXHTHUMB
member.summary: The width of the thumb box in a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXICON
member.summary: The default width of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions that SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON specifies.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXICONSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size SM_CXICONSPACING by SM_CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CXICON.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default width, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum width of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXMENUCHECK
member.summary: The width of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXMENUSIZE
member.summary: The width of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXMIN
member.summary: The minimum width of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXMINIMIZED
member.summary: The width of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXMINSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CXMINIMIZED.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking width of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXPADDEDBORDER
member.summary: The amount of border padding for captioned windows, in pixels. Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, HORZRES).

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXSIZE
member.summary: The width of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXSIZEFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. SM_CXSIZEFRAME is the width of the horizontal border, and SM_CYSIZEFRAME is the height of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CXFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXSMICON
member.summary: The recommended width of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXSMSIZE
member.summary: The width of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_XVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CXVSCROLL
member.summary: The width of a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYBORDER
member.summary: The height of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CYEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a caption area, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYCURSOR
member.summary: The height of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CYFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The height of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. The second click must occur within the rectangle defined by SM_CXDOUBLECLK and SM_CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time. To set the height of the double-click rectangle, call SystemParametersInfo with SPI_SETDOUBLECLKHEIGHT.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels above and below a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from above the mouse-down point and added below it.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYEDGE
member.summary: The height of a 3-D border, in pixels. This is the 3-D counterpart of SM_CYBORDER.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. SM_CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border, and SM_CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CYDLGFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The height of the top and bottom edges of the focus rectangle drawn byDrawFocusRect. This value is in pixels. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as SM_CYSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYHSCROLL
member.summary: The height of a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYICON
member.summary: The default height of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYICONSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size SM_CXICONSPACING by SM_CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CYICON.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYKANJIWINDOW
member.summary: For double byte character set versions of the system, this is the height of the Kanji window at the bottom of the screen, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default height, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum height of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYMENU
member.summary: The height of a single-line menu bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYMENUCHECK
member.summary: The height of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYMENUSIZE
member.summary: The height of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYMIN
member.summary: The minimum height of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYMINIMIZED
member.summary: The height of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYMINSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CYMINIMIZED.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking height of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, VERTRES).

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYSIZE
member.summary: The height of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYSIZEFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. SM_CXSIZEFRAME is the width of the horizontal border, and SM_CYSIZEFRAME is the height of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CYFRAME.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYSMCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a small caption, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYSMICON
member.summary: The recommended height of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYSMSIZE
member.summary: The height of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_YVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the coordinates for the top of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYVSCROLL
member.summary: The height of the arrow bitmap on a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.CYVTHUMB
member.summary: The height of the thumb box in a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.DBCSENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if User32.dll supports DBCS; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.DEBUG
member.summary: Nonzero if the debug version of User.exe is installed; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.DIGITIZER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The return value is a bitmask that specifies the type of digitizer input supported by the device. For more information, see Remarks. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.IMMENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if Input Method Manager/Input Method Editor features are enabled; otherwise, 0. SM_IMMENABLED indicates whether the system is ready to use a Unicode-based IME on a Unicode application. To ensure that a language-dependent IME works, check SM_DBCSENABLED and the system ANSI code page. Otherwise the ANSI-to-Unicode conversion may not be performed correctly, or some components like fonts or registry settings may not be present.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.MAXIMUMTOUCHES
member.summary: Nonzero if there are digitizers in the system; otherwise, 0. SM_MAXIMUMTOUCHES returns the aggregate maximum of the maximum number of contacts supported by every digitizer in the system. If the system has only single-touch digitizers, the return value is 1. If the system has multi-touch digitizers, the return value is the number of simultaneous contacts the hardware can provide. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.MEDIACENTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP, Media Center Edition, 0 if not.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.MENUDROPALIGNMENT
member.summary: Nonzero if drop-down menus are right-aligned with the corresponding menu-bar item; 0 if the menus are left-aligned.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.MIDEASTENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if the system is enabled for Hebrew and Arabic languages, 0 if not.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.MOUSEPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse is installed; otherwise, 0. This value is rarely zero, because of support for virtual mice and because some systems detect the presence of the port instead of the presence of a mouse.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.MOUSEHORIZONTALWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a horizontal scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.MOUSEWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a vertical scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.NETWORK
member.summary: The least significant bit is set if a network is present; otherwise, it is cleared. The other bits are reserved for future use.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.PENWINDOWS
member.summary: Nonzero if the Microsoft Windows for Pen computing extensions are installed; zero otherwise.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.REMOTECONTROL
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment to determine if the current Terminal Server session is being remotely controlled. Its value is nonzero if the current session is remotely controlled; otherwise, 0. You can use terminal services management tools such as Terminal Services Manager (tsadmin.msc) and shadow.exe to control a remote session. When a session is being remotely controlled, another user can view the contents of that session and potentially interact with it.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.REMOTESESSION
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment. If the calling process is associated with a Terminal Services client session, the return value is nonzero. If the calling process is associated with the Terminal Services console session, the return value is 0. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: The console session is not necessarily the physical console. For more information, seeWTSGetActiveConsoleSessionId.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.SAMEDISPLAYFORMAT
member.summary: Nonzero if all the display monitors have the same color format, otherwise, 0. Two displays can have the same bit depth, but different color formats. For example, the red, green, and blue pixels can be encoded with different numbers of bits, or those bits can be located in different places in a pixel color value.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.SECURE
member.summary: This system metric should be ignored; it always returns 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.SERVERR2
member.summary: The build number if the system is Windows Server 2003 R2; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.SHOWSOUNDS
member.summary: Nonzero if the user requires an application to present information visually in situations where it would otherwise present the information only in audible form; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.SHUTTINGDOWN
member.summary: Nonzero if the current session is shutting down; otherwise, 0. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.SLOWMACHINE
member.summary: Nonzero if the computer has a low-end (slow) processor; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.STARTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 Starter Edition, Windows Vista Starter, or Windows XP Starter Edition; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.SWAPBUTTON
member.summary: Nonzero if the meanings of the left and right mouse buttons are swapped; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.TABLETPC
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP Tablet PC edition or if the current operating system is Windows Vista or Windows 7 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The SM_DIGITIZER setting indicates the type of digitizer input supported by a device running Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2. For more information, see Remarks.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.XVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_CXVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the width of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.SM_.YVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the top of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The SM_CYVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the height of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_HIDE
member.summary: Hides the window and activates another window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_NORMAL
member.summary: Activates and displays a window. If the window is minimized or maximized, the system restores it to its original size and position. An application should specify this flag when displaying the window for the first time.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_SHOWMINIMIZED
member.summary: Activates the window and displays it as a minimized window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_SHOWMAXIMIZED
member.summary: Activates the window and displays it as a maximized window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_SHOWNOACTIVATE
member.summary: Displays a window in its most recent size and position. This value is similar to , except the window is not activated.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_SHOW
member.summary: Activates the window and displays it in its current size and position.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_MINIMIZE
member.summary: Minimizes the specified window and activates the next top-level window in the Z order.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_SHOWMINNOACTIVE
member.summary: Displays the window as a minimized window. This value is similar to , except the window is not activated.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_SHOWNA
member.summary: Displays the window in its current size and position. This value is similar to , except the window is not activated.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_RESTORE
member.summary: Activates and displays the window. If the window is minimized or maximized, the system restores it to its original size and position. An application should specify this flag when restoring a minimized window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_SHOWDEFAULT
member.summary: Sets the show state based on the SW_* value specified in the STARTUPINFO structure passed to the CreateProcess function by the program that started the application.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.ShowWindowCommands.SW_FORCEMINIMIZE
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: Minimizes a window, even if the thread that owns the window is not responding. This flag should only be used when minimizing windows from a different thread.

member.summary: I needed some "Generic" magic to get from an enum to an int for switch and boolean operands

member.name: T:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.CS_
member.summary: CS_*

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.GetWindowType.GW_HWNDFIRST
member.summary:
The retrieved handle identifies the window of the same type that is highest in the Z order.
If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.GetWindowType.GW_HWNDLAST
member.summary:
The retrieved handle identifies the window of the same type that is lowest in the Z order.
If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.GetWindowType.GW_HWNDNEXT
member.summary:
The retrieved handle identifies the window below the specified window in the Z order.
If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.GetWindowType.GW_HWNDPREV
member.summary:
The retrieved handle identifies the window above the specified window in the Z order.
If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.GetWindowType.GW_OWNER
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the specified window's owner window, if any.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.GetWindowType.GW_CHILD
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the child window at the top of the Z order, if the specified window is a parent window; otherwise, the retrieved handle is NULL. The function examines only child windows of the specified window. It does not examine descendant windows.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.GetWindowType.GW_ENABLEDPOPUP
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the enabled popup window owned by the specified window (the search uses the first such window found using GW_HWNDNEXT); otherwise, if there are no enabled popup windows, the retrieved handle is that of the specified window.

member.name: M:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.GetWindow(System.IntPtr,Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.GetWindowType)
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to a window that has the specified relationship (Z-Order or owner) to the specified window.
member.remarks: The EnumChildWindows function is more reliable than calling GetWindow in a loop. An application that calls GetWindow to perform this task risks being caught in an infinite loop or referencing a handle to a window that has been destroyed.
member.param: A handle to a window. The window handle retrieved is relative to this window, based on the value of the uCmd parameter.
The relationship between the specified window and the window whose handle is to be retrieved.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is a window handle. If no window exists with the specified relationship to the specified window, the return value is NULL. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: T:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.BlurParams
member.summary: Contains members that specify the nature of a Gaussian blur.
member.remarks: Cannot be pinned with GCHandle due to bool value.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.BlurParams.Radius
member.summary: Real number that specifies the blur radius (the radius of the Gaussian convolution kernel) in pixels. The radius must be in the range 0 through 255. As the radius increases, the resulting bitmap becomes more blurry.

member.name: F:Krypton.Toolkit.Suite.Extended.Common.ToolkitPI.BlurParams.ExpandEdges
member.summary: Boolean value that specifies whether the bitmap expands by an amount equal to the blur radius. If TRUE, the bitmap expands by an amount equal to the radius so that it can have soft edges. If FALSE, the bitmap remains the same size and the soft edges are clipped.
